Synchronous programming allows multiple tasks to run at the same time, while asynchronous programming runs tasks in a sequence.
In synchronous programming, tasks wait for a call to finish before proceeding to the next one, while asynchronous programming does not wait.
Asynchronous programming is mainly used for CPU-bound tasks, whereas synchronous programming is used for I/O operations.
Synchronous programming involves multiple threads, while asynchronous programming cannot use multithreading.

A thread is a lightweight process that cannot run in parallel, while a process can.
A process is a segment of a program that can perform I/O operations, while a thread cannot.
A process is a program in execution, whereas a thread is the smallest sequence of programmed instructions that can be managed independently.
A thread has its own stack and program counter, while a process shares these with other processes.
